headline: IT stocks rise 440 bps from day's low as value buying emerges; Infosys, TCS see sharp recovery
condensed_text: IT stocks rise 440 bps from day's low as value buying emerges; Infosys, TCS see sharp recovery. IT stocks staged a sharp recovery on February 13 as value buying was seen in the battered stocks after they fell up to 6% in morning session on sell-off in the US due to the susceptibility of US companies to disruption by artificial intelligence. Major IT players such as Infosys, Tata Consultancy Services, and Wipro were the worst-hit stocks in the Nifty 50 index. The Nifty IT index fell over 5% to an over 10-month low of 31422.60 points. However, value buying was seen in the stocks with the ten-constituent Nifty IT index rising over 4 percentage points from day's low.

headline: Tata Elxsi, Tata Technologies, Persistent Systems still trade at lofty multiples amidst IT rout
condensed_text:
The decline tracked weakness in the benchmark Nifty IT index, which extended losses from the previous session and dropped more than 5 per cent during the day to a low of 31,422.60 from its previous close of 33,160.20. Since February 2026, the index has corrected about 18.6 per cent from its high of 38,611.75, with heavyweight constituents including Tata Consultancy Services, Infosys and HCLTech acting as major drags. TCS, Wipro, Infosys stocks fall as AI fears drag Nifty IT index down
Tata Technologies fell about 11 per cent to ₹575.30, trading at a multiple near 50, while Persistent Systems slipped 12.5 per cent to a low of ₹5,210. Coforge plunged 17 per cent to ₹1,334, Happiest Minds Technologies declined more than 9 per cent to ₹365, and KPIT Technologies dropped over 18 per cent to ₹812.90. Shares of Infosys dropped 16 per cent during the week to a low of ₹1,281.50 in today’s trade, while Tata Consultancy Services fell 14 per cent over the past week to touch a low of ₹2,585.
Sector: NIFTY IT, NIFTY MIDSMALL IT & TELECOM

headline: Telcos can't hold spectrum amid bankruptcy proceedings: SC
condensed_text: Telcos can't hold spectrum amid bankruptcy proceedings: SC. In a significant ruling, the Supreme Court of India rejected an appeal from lenders and defaulting telcos seeking to classify spectrum as an asset during the bankruptcy resolution.The decision came in cases involving Aircel and Reliance Communications, and their lenders  who argued that excluding spectrum from resolution processes would render any revival efforts futile, leaving "nothing to resolve."The appellants urged the court to recognise the right to use spectrum as a transferable asset, enabling its utilisation in restructuring distressed telecom entities.However, the bench held that the Insolvency and Bankruptcy cannot guide the principles governing spectrum ownership and control.The court affirmed that spectrum constitutes a "material resource of the community," with its ownership and control needing to be safeguarded for public interest rather than private insolvency proceedings.The Centre had backed this stance, contending that spectrum is a national resource not amenable to restructuring under the IBC, preventing its commodification in corporate defaults.Track the latest Q3 earnings here.Read more: Explained | Why gold is suddenly trading at a discount in India
